The rest of the active players were very widely spread out across the 100's, 200's, and 300's. #150 Daniel Crutcher submitted a set of 23 PR's, which bumped him up 17 places. #200 Rob Jon had also been hard at work. He PR'ed 11 times, cut ~4.5 AF, and...didn't move anywhere at all. At least he's past the better part of the AF chasm, now. #223 Florian Truetschel sent in a large batch of times as well--25, to be exact. He jumped forward 21 places, with a nice ~26 point cut to his AF. #234 Julian Stephens moved at a more sedate pace, content to simply cut ~1.9 AF with 4 PR's and maintain his current rank (though it's not nearly as cool without the 1). #260 Russell Horwood was the only active player outside the Top 100 to lose ground in AF, perhaps because he only PR'ed twice. At least he didn't fall back quite as much as the karters around him. #359 Stephen de Winter made perhaps the most efficient move. Amidst all the karters forging ahead with massive quantities of PR's, Stephen managed to cut exactly three and a half points of AF and leapfrog 3 karters with just 2 PR's. And finally, #384 Michael Vogt cut just over 28 points of AF with that many PR's, enough to shoot past 12 players. It's a lot easier to make those big cuts in the lower ranks, so enjoy them while you can.


Site Records
There was just one new Site Record this week. RVZ managed to steal glitchmeister Donkey's last SR and his place on the SR rankings, at tied 13th along with many other 1-hit wonders.

Robert van Zanten beat Marvin Donjes's old Mario Circuit lap time of 0'09"749 with a time of: 0'09"731


Awards
4th POW of March: Leo Petiard - With 14 PR's, Leo easily takes this award, jumping forward 7 places to #24 and cutting ~9.83% of his total AF.
1st POW of April: Salvatore Bellusci - Salvatore made a return to MKWii this week, quickly earning 6 PR's and cutting ~1.16 points of AF, enough to bump him up a spot to #20.
March POM: Artur Bauer - Armed with improvements to a quarter of his timesheet, Mr. Bauer broke into the Top 10 with ease, moving from #12 -> #8 and knocking ~3.78 points (~11.79% of his total) off his AF.
1st POQ of 2012: Leo Petiard - Leo was on fire this quarter, cranking out PR's at an insane rate. In total, he improved 54 of his times; moved from #60 -> #24; and cut nearly 40% off his AF, more than any player above or below him.



~MrL1193

fields.author: MrL1193
fields.title: April PR Showers
fields.content:
Update: April 8th - April 22nd


New Players
Two new challengers joined the fray, an average of one per week.

Michael Pumberger's starter set consisted of the usual 32 course times. He would be ranked 356th if every one of his flaps were ranked dead last, but since that's obviously not the case, he can easily improve just by completing his timesheet.
Daniel B decided to emphasize quality over quantity and only sent in 6 course times. They were quite good on average, though, two of them even ranking in the Top 10's. Altogether, his theoretical rank is 397th for now.

Movement
Altogether, a solid 32 players were at work.

~~1-10~~
The Top 10 saw plenty of activity from its elite members. #2 Jay Batten turned up the heat again this week with 4 PR's. He's almost come within 1 AF of champ Jorge now, and doesn't seem likely to reach his limit any time soon. He still has yet to seize any Site Records, though, of which JG has eight. If he keeps up this pattern, he may very well become the first overall champion to hold no SR's at all--which would be kind of cool but probably a bit annoying for him as well. #6 Artur Bauer made some nice progress as well, outpacing #7 Dustin Enders. Dustin rolled out 5 PR's in his move to reclaim his German crown, but Artur cut more than twice as much AF with 6 PR's, stretching his lead to more than 1 AF. And down at the end, #10 Thomas van Deerse felt uncomfortable with his double-digit position and set about remedying that with 5 PR's. He still has almost a full point of AF to go to reach #9 Ruby Aruba, but at least there are no immediate threats from behind him at the moment.

~~11-25~~
The players in this group were pretty busy as well. #16 John Brunn hit 5 PR's and passed 2 karters. #17 Reinier de Jonge was one of them; he PR'ed once but still lost some ground in AF as well as a position. Just below, #19 Salvatore Bellusci kept up a blistering pace, setting a total of 15 new times to pass Alex Shoal and end the week at exactly 43 AF. And rounding out the group, #24 Dave Tandy sent in his usual periodical batch of hoarded PR's. His grand total this time was 26, which cut almost 7 points of AF and sent him rocketing forward that many places, straight into the Top 25.

~~26-50~~
The lower half of the Top 50 wasn't quite so lucky when it came to moving forward. #31 Liam Ashcroft PR'ed twice but couldn't overcome the AF treadmill, and lost a position to Dave to boot. #34 Max Anosova was the only player in the group to move forward, thanks to a dozen hoarded PR's. He leapfrogged 6 karters and cut ~3.56 AF. #41 Matthias Sempels and #47 Franco Gubser were left in the dust; they each PR'ed once (and Matthias actually could have passed Max if he had stayed where he was), but they ended up taking a net loss in AF.

~~51-100~~
Progress picks up again outside the Top 50. #54 Andre Hoelscher made terrific progress with 10 PR's, jumping forward 8 places and reaching King A rank in ARR. #67 Dilan Arse didn't do too badly himself, gaining one place with 5 PR's and cutting almost a full point of AF. #76 Carter Clem used his 5 PR's to climb 3 places, while #93 Viktor Silivanov improved 5 spots with 10 PR's. #99 Christian W finishes the group; his rank didn't change, but he did cut ~3.6 AF with 12 PR's.

~~101+~~
#108 Martin Prigent found some time to play MKWii again recently. It seems he still had MK7 on the brain, though, as he stopped at a lucky 7 PR's. He cut about 4 points of AF and exactly that many places. A bit lower down, #136 Evan Simmons returned after a long absence to update 25 of his times. This resulted in an AF cut of exactly 47 and a half points--the most by far in terms of percentages (though not in raw points), and enough to blaze past 32 karters. #144 Qi Zhu is a newcomer to the full AF chart; he's been on the site for a while now, but only recently found time to complete his set of times, earning a solid rank on the chart. #149 Daniel Crutcher was the most conservative mover of the post-100 field; he settled for just 2 new PR's, moving up only 1 spot. #170 Murray Wright, like Evan above, had been absent for some time, but he popped up unexpectedly with 26 new PR's, shooting forward 16 places. #191 Rob Jon was determined to make some progress this week after being stymied earlier. Throwing superstition to the winds, he submitted exactly 13 PR's, including a large batch on Friday the 13th, and went up 9 places to cement himself in the Top 200. Continuing on down the line, we find that #256 Russell Horwood was hard at work as well. He improved to the tune of 20 PR's, which netted him a 4 place improvement. And finally, #364 Krystian Wieczorek also got 20 PR's, which catapulted him forward 50 places and cut ~76.6 points from his AF, the most this update. We'll see if he can add MKWii to his list of karting conquests in the future.


Site Records
None.


Awards
2nd POW of April: Andre Hoelscher - Though there was a good bit of activity among the top players, Andre outshined them all. 10 PR's netted him an 8 place improvement and an ~8.67 point/~9.46% AF cut, the best in the Top 100.
3rd POW of April: John Brunn- With little activity and only a few hoarders as his competition, John stepped up this week. 4 PRs bringing a 1.7 AF cut and a two place improvement, he ran away with the award this week.



~MrL1193

fields.author: MrL1193
fields.title: The Chase Renewed
fields.content:
Update: April 22nd - May 15th


New Players
None this time.

Movement
A total of 25 players have been active since the last update, mostly in the upper ranks.

~~1-10~~
At the top of the ladder, #1 Jorge Hernandez put in an appearance after being absent for a couple month, perhaps because he noticed #2 Jay Batten getting too close for comfort. They each PR'ed 4 times, and though Jay briefly closed the gap between them to 1 AF, Jorge quickly pulled away and brought his AF under 6 points again. #5 Marc Bas also made an unexpected return, cutting exactly 1/8 of a point of AF with a PR on Shy Guy Beach. The only player in the Top 10 to improve his rank, though, was #8 Thomas van Deerse, who passed 2 players by cutting nearly 3 AF with 11 PR's. He doesn't have much further to go to pass a couple more karters, and knowing Thomas, he'll probably have it done in no time.

~~11-25~~
Moving on, we find #16 John Brunn plodding along as usual. He picked up 4 PR's for a modest half point AF cut, which was enough to cross the 40 AF threshold. #18 Salvatore Bellusci isn't too far behind; with 8 PR's, he knocked ~1.4 points off his AF and passed Australian champ Jimmy Benson. #21 Leo Petiard was the busiest player this update, though; with 19 PR's, he cut just over 5 points of AF, or nearly 10% of his total, allowing him to jump forward 4 places. #24 Alvin Le was one of the unlucky karters displaced by this move, but he did manage to mitigate his AF losses with a return similar to Marco's, also earning a PR on Shy Guy Beach.

~~26-50~~
Activity takes a bit of a dip here. #31 Liam Ashcroft improved his Peach Beach time, earning a higher rank on the Worldwide Top 10 but not doing much damage control on the AF front. #47 Franco Gubser was the only other player active in the Top 50. He used his 3 PR's to strengthen his position and move up on Daniel Anderson and the next cluster of karters.

~~51-100~~
To start off this group, we have a pair of karters who broke the 100 AF barrier. #65 Dilan Arse and #66 Sean Owens were far apart before this update, but are now next-door neighbors, thanks to a big 17 PR's from Sean that pushed him forward 16 places. Arsenic didn't do too badly himself, gaining 2 places with 6 PR's. Just below in the 70's bracket, #76 Carter Clem came up with 3 PR's, which would have bumped him up a spot but didn't due to Sean flying past him. And rounding out the group, #91 Christian W followed Sean's lead and moved 8 places to buddy up with #92 Jon Coppernoll. Jon was none too pleased with this arrangement, as he had to give up a position to Christian, but his 3 PR's couldn't compete with Christian's round dozen.

~~101+~~
With no rookies to add to the ranks, the post-100 field didn't have much activity to speak of. #103 Martin Prigent seems to be taking advantage of this by passing up as many inactive karters as he can. He managed to pass 5 of them with 8 PR's, but there's a decent-sized gap after the next player, Noah Gordon, so Martin will have to keep working hard if he wants to make it into the Top 100. #113 Evan Simmons may have designs on the Top 100 as well; with his 15 PR's, he cut nearly 30 points of AF and jumped forward 23 places. And finally, #145 Daniel Crutcher made an efficient 4 place cut with just 2 PR's, pulling away from both the 150 border and the 200 AF mark.


Site Records
Three Site Records were improved, which is about the average rate these days. The one record to change hands was taken from Tony Ros by none other than Jay Batten, finally getting him onto the SR table. Tony was left with two, which dropped him to tied 6th place in the rankings.

Sam Fairless improved his own Mushroom Gorge crs time of 0'30"769 with a time of: 0'30"369
Jay Batten beat Tony Ros's Mario Circuit crs time of 1'04"984 with a time of: 1'04"361
Cole Gilbert improved his own GCN Peach Beach crs time of 1'13"097 with a time of: 1'13"023


Awards
4th POW of April: Jay Batten - Jay kept up his brisk pace this week with 4 PR's, more than most other karters in the Top 100. With this cut, he cut down Jorge's lead to less than 1 AF for the first time in about a year.
April POM: Artur Bauer - For the second month in a row, Artur took a break from his usual hoarding and started PR'ing rapidly, racking up 12 in all and moving from #8 -> #6. His ~3.66 AF cut amounted to ~12.92% of his total, the largest proportional cut in the Top 100.
1st POW of May: Thomas van Deerse - With not a soul outside the Top 100 stirring, Thomas cruised to an easy victory this week. His 5 PR's allowed him to overtake Aruba for the #9 spot and earned him a hefty 1.5 AF cut.
2nd POW of May: Thomas van Deerse - Another quiet week allowed Thomas to double up on POW's with just 4 PR's, cutting just short of a full point of AF and passing Jak Russo for the #8 spot.



~MrL1193

fields.author: MrL1193
fields.title: Turning Up the Heat for Summer
fields.content:
Update: May 15th - June 1st


New Players
Denis Bejolli was the only new recruit. His starting set of 30 course times would be enough on their own for 258th place, though the addition of lap times would ensure further cuts.

Movement
Activity rebounded this update, as no fewer than 30 players sent in new times, including a few returning from sabbaticals. It looks like Mario Kart Wii has life in it yet!

~~1-10~~
The biggest news this update is that #2 Jay Batten is now less than half a point of AF away from champ Jorge. Despite already being so highly ranked, he accumulated an astounding 15 PR's during this 2-week period, cutting exactly 10% from his AF. Jorge has shown signs of fighting back, so stay tuned--things are about to get interesting.
In other news, #5 Marc Bas was one of several players who made a comeback this May, and he continued his activity in the latter half of the month with 1 PR, though he still has a long way to go to reach #4 Nick Meade. #7 Thomas van Deerse turned up as well, earning a cut of ~.7 AF with 4 PR's. And #10 Ruby Aruba came up with 2 PR's to pull his AF under 29, less than 1 point away from #9 Jak Russo.

~~11-26~~
#14 Lee Duggan submitted a good batch of 8 PR's to knock roughly 5% off his AF total, passing the retired David McPartland. #16 Salvatore Bellusci submitted more PR's than anyone else in the Top 100; his massive burst of activity paid off, bumping him up 2 spots. #17 John Brunn was one of the players demoted by this move, but he eked out 2 PR's to at least mitigate his AF losses. #21 Leo Petiard is coming up fast behind both of them; his rank didn't change this update, but he cut ~1.8 AF with 5 PR's, stopping just short of Alex Shoal and the Top 20. And rounding out and stretching beyond the Top 25, we have a long string of consecutive active karters. #23 Cole Gilbert, #24 Alvin Le, #25 Dave Tandy, and #26 Matthieu Mayer all sent in varying numbers of PR's for varying AF cuts, Dave's hoarded dozen being the largest of the submissions. Since they weren't too close together to begin with and all moved in the same direction, they all kept their original ranks, though since they're now clustered quite close together, there's likely to be a shakeup before long.

~~27-50~~
Since I broke my grouping system and lumped Matthieu into the group above, #31 Liam Ashcroft gets this paragraph all to himself. He used his 2 PR's to exactly halve his AF losses, his rank remaining unchanged. And that's it for the Top 50!

~~51-100~~
Some more familiar faces greet us as we continue on through the Top 100. #53 Andre Hoelscher made a nice cut of ~4 AF with 9 PR's, working his way up one rank. #65 Sean Owens and #66 Dilan Arse found themselves wedged together after the last update, and they stayed that way this update, though they somehow managed to switch positions despite Dilan PR'ing twice as many times as Sean. Arsenic took a hit in AF while Sean gained ground with just 2 PR's, but they're both still under the 100 AF mark for now. Down below, #88 Christian W made a solid cut of ~3.8 AF with 12 PR's, passing 3 players as he ventures deeper into the Top 100. #92 Viktor Silivanov marks the end of the group's activity, with 4 PR's securing a 2 place cut.

~~101+~~
#102 Martin Prigent kicks off the post-100 activity, with 4 PR's bringing him ~2.9 AF and 1 place closer to the Top 100. A bit farther out, #119 Luke Berrill showed up again after a long break, turning in 9 PR's for a 1 place improvement. #123 Daniel Crutcher won the competition for sheer volume of PR's this update, with a massive load of 29 shooting him forward ~27.7 AF and 22 places. #152 Blake Germany's got a new SR on DKSC lap this update, but it didn't help his AF much. #160 Fabio Sacco was in a similar situation with 2 less-lofty PR's, but any small cut to offset the treadmill effect is better than nothing. #163 Murray Wright sent in the second-largest batch of PR's this update after Daniel's--25 in all--though he "only" improved by 7 places and ~15.5 AF. And finally, #262 Josh Miller joined the throng of returning players with 10 PR's, climbing up 4 places.


Site Records
A lot of Site Records fell during the second half of May--6 in all--and most of them changed hands as well. In the shakeup of SR totals that resulted, Jay claimed his second SR, though he still doesn't have any WR's so far. Cole completed his set of rPB records by snagging the flap, while MG specialist Sam Fairless did likewise on his own course. Blake once again took his friend Ethan's place on the SR table by claiming the DKSC lap record. And finally, John Brunn came up with a new strat for the MH lap and, after a brief battle with Jimbo and a few others, managed to claim and retain the record to earn his place on the SR table. The other players who lost SR's were Paul-Philipp Baehr, Nick Meade, and Romain Smadja (who fell into a 3-way tie for 2nd with Sword and Lee, with 4 SR's left).


Sam Fairless beat Paul-Philipp Baehr's Mushroom Gorge lap time of 0'09"174 with a time of: 0'09"146
Blake Germany beat Ethan McCormac's DK's Snowboard Cross lap time of 0'35"298 with a time of: 0'35"251
Lee Duggan improved his own Dry Dry Ruins crs time of 1'48"275 with a time of: 1'48"008
John Brunn beat Jamie Disley's Moonview Highway lap time of 0'33"322 with a time of: 0'33"195
Cole Gilbert beat Romain Smadja's old GCN Peach Beach lap time of 0'22"447 with a time of: 0'22"445
Jay Batten beat Nick Meade's N64 Bowser's Castle crs time of 2'31"752 with a time of: 2'31"694


Awards
3rd POW of May: Leo Petiard - Despite neither earning the most PR's nor improving his rank, Leo had the best non-hoarded AF cut in the Top 100 by a comfortable margin, knocking off ~1.92 points/~4.11% with 5 PR's.
4th POW of May: Salvatore Bellusci - There was fierce competition among various top players this week, but Salvatore just barely edges out the others by virtue of more consistent updating. His massive 12 PR load took off ~1.95 points/~4.79% from his AF and bumped him up one spot to #16.
May POM: Thomas van Deerse - Thomas was the only player in the Top 100 to push his percentage AF cut into double digits (~10.75%). He accomplished this with 13 PR's and a ~3.14 point cut, moving from #10 -> #7 in the rankings.


~MrL1193

fields.author: MrL1193
fields.title: New Season, New Champion
fields.content:
Update: June 1st - July 1st


New Players
The site saw a lot of new faces in the month of June--6 in all. Out of all of them, only Kosta Nasiovas is equipped with a full timesheet so far, the highlight of them being a sub 1:32 on GCN Mario Circuit. Currently ranked #124 in AF, he seems to be off to a solid start.

Koopa Cape specialist Raiga Ozaki also distinguished himself from the other joiners. He only submitted 10 times, but one of them was the new Koopa Cape SR. Combined his other times, it guarantees him at least 381st.

The other new players, their number of submitted times, and their theoretical ranks are:
Sergio Garcia: 26 times, 288th
Jeremi Husson: 33 times, 291st
Colin Koenig: 32 times, 308th
Oriol Solsona: 32 times, 336th


Movement
The advent of summer in the northern hemisphere brought on a flood of karting activity, with no fewer than 58 players active. As is often the case, a lot of the activity was near the top, and a lot of SR's were cut down as well. Oh, and there was also the small matter of the battle for the crown...

~~1-10~~
So, as you all know, there's been a lengthy battle going on between our top two players, Jay Batten and Jorge Hernandez. Time and time again, Jay would approach Jorge's lofty throne, only to be rebuffed yet again. But Jay never gave up, continually improving, focusing on cutting AF rather than accumulating WR's. Jorge put up fierce resistance, improving 18 of his times and plunging his AF under the 5 point mark for the first time in many months. But Jay did likewise with his own PR's, which numbered 31 in all--nearly half his timesheet! And so, after a reign of more than 400 consecutive days--the longest single span in MKWii history--Jorge was dethroned. Congratulations to our new champion, Jay Batten!

The other players in the Top 10 weren't completely idle themselves, though their activity had nothing on Jay and Jorge. #3 Shaun Tanney managed a couple PR's, though he still lost ground in AF. French champion #5 Marc Bas was also active, actually cutting AF with his 3 PR's. Dutch star #6 Thomas van Deerse has his eye on Marc; he cut over a full point of AF with 9 PR's and passed German champ Artur Bauer. There's still a gap of more than 6 points ahead of Thomas, though, so Marc probably isn't worried yet. #9 Jak Russo PR'ed only once, but it was a pretty good PR--a Site Record, in fact. It was also enough for him to cut a bit of AF. And finally, #10 Ruby Aruba came up with a few PR's this month, but they weren't enough to keep his AF from slipping a bit.

~~11-25~~
Meanwhile, #15 Matthieu Mayer seems to be following in Jay's footsteps, racking up PR's left and right. He scored 29 in all, enough to chop more than 27% off his AF and jump back into the Top 20 all the way from #26. #17 Salvatore Bellusci and #18 John Brunn were both victims of this move, but they both stayed active to cut AF and prevent any further losses. And indeed, they shouldn't rest easy, as #19 Leo Petiard is hot on their tails now. He mustered an impressive 19 PR's to gain 2 places despite being passed by Matthieu. Swiss champion #23 Alvin Le also defied the odds, improving his rank by 1 despite barely cutting any AF.

~~26-50?~~
#28 Liam Ashcroft has been putting a good deal of time into GCN Peach Beach lately, but he apparently still found time to improve 6 different times in all, passing 3 players. #32 Clement Rouchon sent in a big batch of 19 PR's, bounding forward 11 places and cutting over 10 AF. #41 Zane Royal was bumped down a spot by Clement's move. His 2 PR's didn't help his AF much, either, but did garner some recognition over in the SR department. And down at the 50 border, #48 Sebastian Kovats and #49 Andre Hoelscher pushed forward 1 and 4 ranks respectively to sandwich Marvin Rekovsky between them in the rankings list. What's that? You say there's no position in between 48th and 49th? Well, you see, Marvin started the month at 48th, but Sebastian managed to get ahead of him, while Andre moved up from outside the Top 50 to precisely tie Marvin but appears immediately below him in the AF rankings. So, technically, Marvin does appear right in between them. And that finishes off the Top 50!...Or is it the Top 49? Whatever, let's just move on. :P

~~51-100~~
Veteran #54 Gary Marcoz unexpectedly got a large portion of his timesheet updated--23 times in all. He cut over 20 points and 20% off his AF and rocketed forward 15 places. #58 Danny Gallenberger made a slight return to Mario Kart Wii, just enough to earn 1 PR. He didn't overcome the AF treadmill, though, and lost a position to boot because of Gary. #65 Sean Owens also lost more ground than he gained, but at least his rank remained unchanged. #71 Carter Clem seemed to be having some trouble maintaining access to a functional Wii this month, but he still managed to forge past 5 more karters, and with only 3 PR's, too. His impressive efficiency makes a striking contrast to #85 Christian W's June activity, as he PR'ed 14 times but only gained 3 places. Player spacing is largely to blame, as Christian did cut a tidy ~4.8 AF. #89 Jon Coppernoll had to overcome a ~3.5 AF gap himself after overtaking 1 karter, but he managed to reach the other side and pass 3 more players, for a 4 place gain overall. And rounding out the group, we have a new face in the Top 100, #94 Daniel Crutcher. Daniel was extremely active in June, cranking out 46 PR's for a ~38 AF cut and 29 place cut, barreling through like a steam train straight into the Top 100. Nice work, Daniel!

~~101+~~
The Crutcher Express left several disgruntled travelers standing on the platform, watching the train disappear into the Top 100 without them. #101 Martin Prigent is one of these unfortunates; making his way forward from #102 in the line, his 9 PR's would have been enough for a ticket into the Top 100, but he got left out in the cold when Daniel grabbed the last seat. #102 Loris Bagnasco actually was ranked #100, until Daniel kicked him out and Martin knocked him down another spot, but he at least made a small AF cut. He was luckier than #103 Sam Smith, who lost ground in AF as well as positions. He's the third consecutive karter to almost make it into the Top 100, but with Daniel, Martin, and Loris all active, he just dropped 2 places instead. #104 Cyril Fulag isn't helping matters for them; as if they weren't all uncomfortable enough, Cyril came out of nowhere with 44 PR's to rocket forward 30 places and latch onto the tail end of the line. Will any of these karters be able to realize their ambitions? Stay tuned...

#113 Luke Berrill seems to have returned to the MKW TT scene recently. He submitted improvements to 15 times, clambering over 6 karters. #118 Virgil Blondel unexpectedly turned up again as well, though his 1 PR didn't keep him from losing 3 places due to the fallout of Daniel and Cyril's moves. #120 Simon Uldry wasn't about to let the terrible two hold him back, though, and cut almost 8 AF with 9 PR's. It was enough to convert his potential loss in positions to a gain of 1. #129 Tom Norton had better things to do than worry about silly things like AF, and concentrated instead on getting the Luigi Circuit WR. As expected, his AF didn't benefit much, but despite dropping a rank in AF, he's well on his way to reaching his goal. #131 Dexter Howe kept busy as well, though his 2 PR's weren't quite enough to prevent him from losing a place and some ground in AF. #138 Qi Zhu improved a quarter of his timesheet for a solid 7 place gain. #140 Christian Nemetz wasn't so lucky; he earned 6 PR's and cut a point of AF, but lost 2 places anyway. #149 James Leare lost a spot as well, though his 1 PR didn't result in net progress in AF. #181 Nicola Torre managed to find some time off from MK7 updating to play MKWii, it seems, and he made quite a nice cut. With just 6 PR's, he skipped ahead 8 places, cutting 12.75 AF. #188 Rob Jon's improvements were more spread out, as he shaved off ~10.8 AF and 3 places with 16 different PR's. #203 Pierre Ruffin joined the ever-growing "Where did you come from, long time no see" crowd to cut a cool 16.5 AF and 4 places, though, sadly, none of his 9 PR's were on Mushroom Gorge. And last but not least, #253 Russell Horwood cut exactly 1 point of AF with 4 PR's, moving up 3 places.


Site Records
Both SR and WR activity boomed this month along with regular activity. Among the multi-SR holders, Jorge Hernandez lost 1, though with 7 SR's, he still holds more than anyone else. Jay Batten promised to start going after WR's after he gained the AF crown, and he made good on his promise, adding 3 of them to his former 2 and taking 2nd place in SR totals. Lee Duggan lost 1, dropping him to 4th place. Tom Norton fell to tied 5th after losing 2, and was the only player to lose more than 1 SR this month. Zane Royal moved up to join that same 10-way tie, doubling his SR count to 2. Jak Russo, Alex Bjorkman, and Raiga Ozaki made their way onto the table with 1 SR apiece, while Reinier de Jonge, Matthieu Mayer, and Thomas Ullrich lost their last SR's and were kicked off entirely.
An honorable mention goes to Kunio Oniku, who held the N64 Mario Raceway Course WR for a period of time in June, but had lost it back to Zane by the time of this update.

Jay Batten beat Matthieu Mayer's old Moo Moo Meadows crs time of 1'15"859, had a quick WR battle with Matthieu following that, and came out on top with a time of: 1'15"742
Sam Fairless improved his own Mushroom Gorge crs time of 0'30"369 with a time of: 0'28"976
Sam Fairless also improved his own Mushroom Gorge lap time of 0'09"146 with a time of: 0'08"440
Raiga Ozaki beat Jorge Hernandez's old Koopa Cape crs time of 2'20"374 with a time of: 2'20"259
Alex Bjorkman beat Thomas Ullrich's old Grumble Volcano crs time of 0'19"578 with a time of: 0'19"503
Jak Russo beat Lee Duggan's old Dry Dry Ruins lap time of 0'33"176 with a time of: 0'33"062
Cole Gilbert improved his own GCN Peach Beach crs time of 1'13"023 with a time of: 1'12"992
Zane Royal defended his N64 Mario Raceway crs record, improving his old time of 1'41"732 with a time of: 1'41"671
Jay Batten beat Reinier de Jonge's old N64 Mario Raceway lap time of 0'31"597 with a time of: 0'31"480
Jay Batten beat Tom Norton's old GBA Shy Guy Beach lap time of 0'25"247 with a time of: 0'25"156
Zane Royal beat Tom Norton's old DS Delfino Square crs time of 2'05"167 with a time of: 2'05"156
Luis G improved his own SNES Mario Circuit 3 crs time of 1'18"230 with a time of: 1'18"205
Jay Batten improved his own N64 Bowser's Castle crs time of 2'31"694 with a time of: 2'31"645


Awards
1st POW of June: Jay Batten - This was the week that it finally happened. After a long struggle, Jay finally overwhelmed Jorge with an incredible 24 PR's, becoming Myth C in ARR. With a massive 1.5 point cut, he subbed 5 points in AF and became the new site champion!
2nd POW of June: Matthieu Mayer - Though Jay and Jorge were strong contenders for this award, Matthieu crushed all competition, moving from #26 to #17 with a stunning 23 PR's. He cut over 12 AF, about ~23.6% of his total.
3rd POW of June: Daniel Crutcher - Far outpacing all other players, Daniel broke into the Top 100 in style, with an impressive 26 PR's. His ~14.4 AF cut was more than twice as large as his nearest competitors' by both points and percentage, propelling him forward 8 places to 100th on the dot.
4th POW of June: Daniel Crutcher - While other players went off on summer vacations, Daniel kept up his activity with 9 PR's. Cutting ~5 points of AF, his encore performance was enough to earn the award for the second week in a row.

I'll edit the rest of the awards in tomorrow, if I can, so keep an eye on this space for a while yet. Have a great summer everybody!


~MrL1193

fields.author: NStride
fields.title: Shout out
fields.content:
It's been ages since I lasted posted here, but I want to mention and thank the efforts of one of this page's very skilled and dedicated players, both on and off the track. That person is Cole Gilbert.

Recently, Cole developed a code that checks for cheaters, basically. It specifically checks for impossibly fast wheelie inputs - if the code detects inhuman input, such as 10 positive wheelie inputs in 20-25 frames, then it is a fact that that player cheated. (The code checks for both rapid fire input and input that indicates the game slowed down and the player button-mashed during the slower fps rate.) It also means that the player lied about the legitimacy of their times and cannot be trusted.

Already, several players near the top have been caught. Formerly recognized page champion Jay Batten has been removed, and Jorge Hernandez also has been caught using slow downs on rMC. Other top 10 players such as Artur and Dustin have also failed Cole's test.

So, to those of you who may be watching the AF go through its current upheaval and have no idea what's going on... well, that's what's going on.

Cole, on behalf of everyone here I want to thank you for all the effort you've put into improving this site and competitive MKWii in general. For creating an excellent site that keeps a historical record of world records, to testing players with a new method for trustworthiness. You had no obligation to do any of this whatsoever, and we really appreciate it.

~Shock

fields.author: MrL1193
fields.title: Aftermath
fields.content:
Update: ? - August 15th

The Purge
As you no doubt have noticed, the site rankings have been going through quite the upheaval lately. This is due to the outstanding work of two site veterans, Cole Gilbert and Marcel Felix. Recently, Cole developed a way to examine the inputs of players' ghost data for superhuman inputs. Marcel made testing easier by creating a repository of ghost data from players around the world and also adding a way to automatically test runs for suspicious inputs. Together, they have contributed to the detection of more than half a dozen cheaters on the Players' Page, as well as some non-site players. Shockingly (or perhaps not, for the cynical), the Top 10 alone contained 4 of the players who were removed, including longtime site champion Jorge Hernandez and newly christened champion Jay Batten. As a result, movement through the AF rankings was rendered difficult to track, due to all the deletions. Thus, I hope you will forgive me for some vagueness on the general activity, and also for any possible omissions. I'll be looking mainly at the August 1st - August 15th stats, with brief mention of other accomplishments that I can remember. I will at least list all the Site Records that changed hands, though.

New Players
Please welcome: Luke Hubbard, Tom Linton, Ben Weber, Marc Robin, Michael Penninck, David, Marcel Ulbrich, Stan Barmentloo, Dante Dhillon. Of the 9, only Ben Weber joined with a full timesheet, jumping in at 245th.

Movement

~~1-10~~
Since the Top 10 lost nearly half of its members in one fell swoop, I'm going to go ahead and list all 10 of the players comprising the new Top 10. (I'll return to normal activity reports after this.) We start with #1 Shaun Tanney, who has been left wearing the site crown after the departure of the two players ahead of him. At ~11.7 AF, he is just over a full point ahead of American Champion #2 Nick Meade. The two have shown some signs of activity, finding new motivation in their newfound ranks. They are both well ahead of #3 Marc Bas, who hasn't yet put in an appearance to comment on recent events. #4 Thomas van Deerse is still active, but he's been in hot water lately for his close ties with Jay. Hopefully the need to remove him as well will not arise. #5 Jak Russo has kept busy as well, picking up a new WR on Delfino Square. #6 Ruby Aruba is the last of the players who were part of the old Top 10. He sits less than a point behind Jak in AF, and seems poised to make a move on him soon. #7 Aziz Abdullah is back in the Top 10 as a result of the removals, though he's shown only slight activity lately. #8 John Brunn is the only newcomer to the Top 10 who's never been in it before, and is staying active trying to hold his position as long as he can. #9 Tony Ros has been away from the game for a while now; with several players coming up on the Top 10 quite quickly, his newfound position in it may be short-lived. And #10 Mark Schmidt has likewise been inactive, probably busy with other Mario Karts, but for now, he once again wears the German crown and the last position in the Top 10. We'll see how long he stays there in weeks to come.

~~11-25~~
Bearing down on Mark like a steam train is #11 Leo Petiard. A good set of PR's has put him less than 1.5 AF away from joining the new Top 10, and he seems intent on reaching that goal. #13 Salvatore Bellusci has stayed slightly active, though the AF treadmill seems to be outpacing him for the moment. And #16 Alex Shoal managed to pull off the new Peach Beach glitch to earn himself a new 3-Lap WR, but still found time to cut plenty of AF to take advantage of the recent purge.

~~26-50~~
The players in this group all seemed to want to stick together in groups, for some reason. Veteran #31 Bob Holden and recent addition to the AF charts #32 Kiver Kivicious made similar cuts with similar numbers of PR's, ensuring that they would remain next-door neighbors. The other active group was the trio of #42 Sean Owens, #44 Sebastian Kovats, and #45 Franco Gubser. Despite appearances, Sean is indeed right next to Sebastian, because he's actually tied for 42nd with Oliver Martin at the moment. Sean also seems to be the fastest-moving member of the group for now, as he shot past the others with more PR's than the two of them combined. Franco is no stranger to the outside border of the Top 50; we'll see if he can hold his position this time.

~~51-100~~
#54 Tim van Ham put in an unexpected appearance after a prolonged absence. His PR count remains modest so far, but that could change in coming weeks. #62 Carter Clem seems to be keeping up steady progress, as is #66 Christian W. #73 Frederick Hutchington popped in with a few PR's as well, bumping himself up a few places. #74 Daniel Crutcher is right behind him, and has been making good progress for some time now. #94 Martin Prigent stayed active to solidify his recently earned position in the Top 100. And #99 Qi Zhu jumped into the Top 100 with a large batch of PR's, just barely passing #100 Luke Berrill, who had also recently reentered the Top 100 after a hiatus. Luke has stayed active as well lately, so he may strike back soon if Qi isn't careful.

~~101+~~
Meanwhile, #102 Evan Simmons has crept within striking distance of the Top 100 now. We'll see if he can make the jump soon. #110 Kosta Nasiovas is not to be counted out either, as he made a fairly large submission recently and may be playing for more. #137 Blake Germany made both DK Summit WR's his own, and may have his sights set on Dry Dry Ruins as well, it seems. #142 Murray Wright released a big set of PR's to make a nice jump forward in the rankings. #246 Russell Horwood returned to play in the aftermath of the cleanup, and seems to be ready to continue his climb through the ranks. #248 Josh Miller joined the growing group of players who made big submissions, moving up a fair way through the ranks. #259 John Koh was yet another returning player, but I'm pretty sure he beats all the others, as it's been years since he last submitted times here. He's making good progress now, and seems to be keeping up activity so far. And finally, #356 Krystian Wieczorek managed to cut a few places with a few PR's to take a few more steps along the road to the top.


Site Records
With Jorge gone, there is no longer any one clearly dominant player on the Site Records table. Romain Smadja and Lee Duggan are currently tied for the lead with 4 SR's apiece. Tom Norton, Nick Meade, and Thomas Petraud are locked in a 3-way tie for 3rd with 3 each. And Max Anosova, Andrew Grieve, Blake Germany, Dave Tandy, Brett Edwards, and Sam Fairless make up the remainder of the players with multiple SR's, the 6 of them being tied for 6th with 2 SR's each.

New Records
Sam Fairless improved his own Mushroom Gorge crs time of 0'28"976 with a time of: 0'27"979
Sam Fairless also improved his Mushroom Gorge lap time of 0'08"440 with a time of: 0'07"289
Sean Owens beat Tony Ros's old Mario Circuit crs time of 1'04"984 with a time of: 1'04"315
Blake Germany beat Andrew Grieve's old DK's Snowboard Cross crs time of 1'49"100 with a time of: 1'48"853
Blake Germany also fended off Ethan McCormac on DK's Snowboard Cross lap, improving his old time of 0'35"251 with a time of: 0'35"140
Lee Duggan beat Jak Russo's old Dry Dry Ruins lap time of 0'33"062 with a time of: 0'33"051
Alex Shoal beat Cole Gilbert's old GCN Peach Beach crs time of 1'12"992 with a time of: 1'09"009, thanks to the new glitch.
Dave Tandy took care of the lap counterpart by beating Cole Gilbert's old GCN Peach Beach lap time of 0'22"445 with a time of: 0'16"744
Jak Russo beat Zane Royal's old DS Delfino Square crs time of 2'05"156 with a time of: 2'05"070
Reinier de Jonge tied Brett Edwards's old DS Peach Gardens crs time of 1'59"824 (with Auto) with a time of: 1'59"824 (with Manual) Neat, eh?
Romain Smadja improved his own DS Peach Gardens lap time of 0'38"544 with a time of: 0'38"507
Dave Tandy beat Tony Ros's old GCN DK Mountain lap time of 0'38"896 with a time of: 0'38"683

Reassigned Records
Kunio Oniku now holds the Moo Moo Meadows crs record with a time of 1'15"966
Marc Bas now holds the Toad's Factory lap record with a time of 0'35"163
Agustin Berrios now holds the Daisy Ciruit crs record with a time of 1'29"685
Ethan McCormac now holds the Daisy Ciruit lap record with a time of 0'28"448
Thomas Petraud now holds the Koopa Cape crs record with a time of 2'20"361
Thomas Ullrich now holds the Grumble Volcano lap record with a time of 0'04"486
Andrew Grieve now holds the Bowser's Castle crs record with a time of 2'11"652
Salvatore Bellusci now holds the Bowser's Castle lap record with a time of 0'42"563
Marvin Donjes now holds the Rainbow Road lap record with a time of 0'48"092
Bapt Johnson now holds the N64 Mario Raceway lap record with a time of 0'31"546
Daniel Anderson now holds the N64 Sherbet Land lap record with a time of 0'39"962
Tom Norton now holds the GBA Shy Guy Beach lap record with a time of 0'25"247
Nick Meade now holds the N64 Bowser's Castle crs record with a time of 2'31"752


Awards
You may have noticed that there are a lot of blanks on the Awards page at the moment. This is because, in order to delete the cheaters, we had to strip them of all their awards. It will take quite some time to sort this mess out, and I cannot say when the missing awards will be reassigned. However, in the interest of keeping the awards from getting even more backed up than they already are, I have decided to start handing out current awards again, starting with this week's. So here it is:

2nd POW of August: Alex Shoal - Alex's push to cut AF paid off this week, earning him a solid 7 PR's. They resulted in a ~2.64 point cut and bumped him up 2 places to 16th.

I'll try to keep the news updates and awards coming as usual from now on. Hopefully, everything will be sorted out soon.


~MrL1193

fields.author: Sean
fields.title: End of Summer
fields.content:
Update: August 15th - September 4th

Hey guys, I'm a brand new updater, commonly known as Malleo. If you haven't noticed, there's been more frequent time updates on the MKW Player's Page. I just became a time and news updater, in hope to make the MKW Player's Page more active and get back in the swing of awarding POWs and such. It might become slightly less active, though, with the start of school.

New Players
Successfully breaking the 1000 members mark, the new players are Jeremy Nesanson, Patrick Chea, Tyler Barrett, Karl Hemmings, Kevin Kuo, Prant San, Nafumo Chan, and Bob Brannen. Of those eight players, only Patrick Chea submitted all 64 times, jumping in at 360th.

Movement
Hey guys, it's MrL1193, here to hijack this news entry. There was a bit of a mix-up with the stats, which resulted in Malleo using the wrong stats to track movement. So, I'm just here to straighten things out.

~~1-10~~
#1 Shaun Tanney and #3 Marc Bas were first up. They each submitted a single PR, not enough to cut AF but enough to mitigate their losses. #4 Thomas van Deerse put in a full 10 PR's, which cut enough AF to bring him under the 20 point threshold. #5 Jak Russo and #6 Ruby Aruba sent in 3 and 4 PR's respectively. They both lost ground in AF, but despite his superior number of PR's, Aruba fell back further than Jak, widening the gap between them to more than 1 full point. #7 John Brunn moved into the position right behind them with 6 PR's, pulling under the 30 AF threshold and passing #9 Aziz Abdullah. And he wasn't the only one to pass Aziz, as #8 Dave Tandy pushed his way into the Top 10. He released a batch of 13 PR's, moving all the way from #15 to join the group.

~~11-25~~
#11 Leo Petiard made a bid for elite status as well with 10 PR's, but fell just short of his goal due to Dave's move. #14 Salvatore Bellusci fell victim to the move as well, losing a place and some ground in AF despite PR'ing twice. #16 Alex Shoal stayed where he was in the rankings; his 6 PR's (including a new Peach Beach WR) kept him from falling back as much as the players around him, so I guess that counts as progress, in a way. #19 Cole Gilbert made solid progress with 13 PR's, cutting 4.25 AF and moving forward 2 places. And #23 Sean Owens and #24 Paul-Philipp Baehr both joined the Top 25 with big batches of PR's, Sean moving 19 places with 34 PR's and Paul moving 3 places with 15.

~~26-50~~
Venturing on through the Top 50, we meet a familiar face, #30 Alvin van Asselt. Alvin used to be the site champion in the early days of the game, and he came back in style this month. He didn't manage to keep from being passed by Sean, but he did grab both Daisy Circuit WR's out of the blue, proving that he's still deserving of his recognition as one of the all-time greats. #31 Kiver Kivicious didn't do too badly himself, nabbing 9 PR's and moving up a spot with a 1.5 AF cut. #33 Bob Holden was unlucky enough to lose not one but two places, but he kept his AF backsliding to a minimum with 3 PR's. #43 Sebastian Kovats actually managed to gain a position while losing ground in AF, his 7 PR's cutting his losses to roughly half what they could have been. And #44 Franco Gubser kept right on Sebastian's tail, moving up 1 spot with him with 5 PR's and closing the gap between them to less than .1 AF.

~~51-100~~
This group was where most of the update's activity was concentrated. #56 Danny Gallenberger found enough time off from MK7 to put in an appearance. He only PR'ed once, but it was worth a decent amount of damage control. #61 Carter Clem, #62 Nate Paternost, #63 Daniel Crutcher, and #64 Dilan Arse all came together in a big block of activity. Carter made the simplest cut, moving ahead 1 place with 6 PR's. Nate and Daniel were the big movers of the bunch, submitting 18 and 17 PR's respectively to leap forward from their original positions of 75th and 74th. Dilan was the unlucky one; he picked up 7 PR's but still lost a place because of Nate and Daniel. #68 Christian W felt the effects of their moves as well, PR'ing a dozen times but still losing 2 spots. #69 Frederick "Jackpot" Hutchington was too busy lining up his cuts to worry about such setbacks. This time, he cut ~4.4 points, roughly ~4% of his AF, with 4 PR's and moved up 4 places. And, incidentally, his MKW points in the Combined Rankings now stand at ~.7777--just as planned, of course. #86 Qi Zhu made terrific progress with a whopping 26 PR's, cutting ~16.6 AF and jumping forward 13 places. #93 Martin Prigent was one of the players Qi passed, but Martin still managed to move up one place with 2 PR's, despite losing ground in AF. #98 Sam Smith's 5 PR's were just enough to cut a bit of AF, but he was left uncomfortably close to the 100 border after being pushed back a spot by Qi. #99 Luke Berrill was eager to get away from there as well, and pushed forward one place with 7 PR's, leaving Cyril Fulag on the brink.

~~100+~~
Activity dropped off sharply outside the Top 100. #124 Dexter Howe stayed alive with 1 PR, though he still dropped back in AF along with everyone around him. #171 Stephen L has been quietly playing under the radar for a while now, and finally decided to make the jump onto the AF chart by completing his timesheet. #222 Stan Barmentloo followed suit, finally sitting down to quickly fill out his Flap times. #245 Russell Horwood kept active with 13 PR's and got 1 place closer to the Top 200. And finally, #297 Andre Riviere returned from a hiatus with 4 PR's, cutting 2 places.

That's it for the corrected movement section. We now return you to your scheduled news update by Malleo.

Site Records
Cole Gilbert beat Jay Boy's Luigi Circuit crs time of 1'09''331 with a time of 1'09''254
Blake Germany improved his own DK's Snowboard Cross crs time of 1'48''853 with a time of 1'48''790
Blake Germany also improved his own DK's Snowboard Cross lap time of 35''140 with a time of 35''022
Alvin van Asselt beat Agustin Berrios' Daisy Circuit crs time of 1'29''658 with a time of 1'29''518
Alvin van Asselt also beat Ethan McCormac's Daisy Circuit lap time of 28''448 with a time of 28''418
Axel San beat Tyler Barrett's Bowser's Castle crs time of 2'11''644 with a time of 2'10''917
Alex Shoal improved his own GCN Peach Beach crs time of 1'09''009 with a time of 1'07''804

Awards
Because of the less frequent updates, we weren't tracking an accurate AF cut. Expect a new POW new week or so.

Thank you guys very much, and keep trying to improve your times!

-Malleoz

fields.author: Sean
fields.title: Fall Has Arrived!
fields.content:
Update: September 4th - September 9th

Fall Has Arrived!
Ahhhh....The sweet, crisp smell of the orange autumn leaves raining down on you, and what better way to kick off this fall than to ruin MKW's fall-themed course? That's right, I am held accountable for breaking Maple Treeway. Anyway, for more info on what the glitch is, look for the thread on the Message Board.

Newcomers
Please welcome the arrival of the following players: Callum Douglas, who submitted all 3lap times and the first 4 flaps, and Philipp Niemier, who submitted all 3lap times as well.

Movement

~~1-10~~
Players #4 Thomas van Deerse, #6 Ruby Aruba, #7 John Brunn, and #8 Dave Tandy all set PRs, but only Thomas van Deerse and John Brunn cut AF.

~~11-25~~
#23 Sean Owens and #24 Paul-Philipp Baehr were the only players to cut AF, but weren't the only ones setting PRs.

~~26-50~~
The only people active were #39 Lucas Acek, #42 Sebastian Kovats, and #43 Franco Gubser. Both Lucas and Sebastian set 4 PRs and cut AF, while Franco only set 1 PR and lost AF.

~~51-100~~
#51 Alberto Fiorese cut 5 AF, amazing setting 17 new PRs. #59 Daniel Crutcher set many PRs, including his MT crs and flap times.

Site Records
Marvin Donjes beat Nick Meade's Maple Treeway crs time of 2'17''350 with a time of 2'06''646 with the new glitch.
Marvin Donjes also beat Fabien Jacques's Maple Treeway lap time of 43''907 with an amazing time of 28''836.


Awards
Sorry, since this wasn't an official week length, I'm not going to post any awards. Next Sunday we will have an award.

-Malleoz

fields.author: Sean
fields.title: Maple Treeway Mayhem!

fields.author: Sean
fields.title: New Season
fields.content:
Update: September 16th - September 23rd

New Members
Please welome Kevin Booth,Josh Frahn, and Jacob Fitzgibbon. Both Josh and Jacob got close to submitting all their times, but missed a few.

Movement

COMBINED

~~1-10~~
#6 Jak Russo did happen to get a great TF time, but he still lost some AF. #6 Ruby Aruba improved two flaps, which gave him a .18 AF cut. #7 John Brunn barely cut any AF after improving both of his rWS times. #8 Dave Tandy, once again, improves his MT times and cuts almost .1 AF. And finally, #9 Aziz Abdullah improves on rDS, but that isn't enough to keep him from losing AF.

fields.author: MrL1193
fields.title: Autumn Reform
fields.content:
Update: September 23rd - October 18th

Hello, John Brunn back at the writer's desk once again to bring you this news update. Before I get to the usual report, there are some announcements I have to make. First of all, some disappointing news--our new updater, Sean Owens (aka Malleo), was caught cheating in his Time Trials. He has admitted to using TAS to get some of his PR's, though it seems likely that they aren't the only ones that were illegitimate. Regardless of the exact extent of his dishonesty, he has been stripped of his updating powers and removed from the Players' Page. The good news, however, is that Zack Weber (aka thewebinator) has volunteered to return to news writing. So, for those of you who have been dissatisfied with the quality of recent news updates, you can rest easy; Web and I will be doing them on alternate weeks from now on, and will hopefully help restore the site to its former glory.

And now, with that out of the way, let's get on with the activity report, shall we?


New Players
Things have been fairly quiet since the last update; only 2 newbies showed up in the nearly month-long span.

Dylan Brown apparently didn't submit any times at all when he joined, so there's no telling where he'd belong on the rankings. Hopefully he'll complete his timesheet soon.
Beat Pika just sent in his 9 best times. In theory, they'd be enough for 377th.

Movement
A good 42 players were active while us news writers weren't. Let's take a look at what everyone accomplished, shall we?

~~1-10~~
Starting things off, #3 Marc Bas dropped in with a PR. He didn't cut much AF, but at this level, any progress is reason for celebration. #4 Thomas van Deerse netted 4 PR's, creeping a little closer to Marc. #5 Ruby Aruba was the busiest karter in the Top 10; he cranked out 11 PR's, and was rewarded by a nearly 1 AF cut--enough to pass Jak Russo. There's a nearly 7 AF gap ahead of him to Thomas, though, so he has a lot more hard work ahead of him to earn his next rank improvement. #7 John Brunn was just barely active, mitigating his losses in AF by the smallest amount possible with 1 PR. And down at the end, #10 Leo Petiard solidified his position in the group with a quarter point cut to his AF, ending up at 33 points even.

~~11-25~~
Well, it seems that I wasn't the only one being lazy this past month after all. In this group, no one played! Well, unless you count our delinquent ex-updater, but I don't think TASing counts. ;) I'm sure the stats will be a right old mess once his removal takes effect, but for now, the stats pages still say everyone's 1 place lower, so that's how I'll write the rest of the news.

~~26-50~~
Things were pretty quiet in this group too, apart from #27 Sebastian Kovats, who sent in 14 PR's to leapfrog 15 karters and cut 12.75 AF. The only other active player was #40 Franco Gubser, whose efforts on the new Maple Treeway glitch weren't enough to save him from falling back in AF and losing a place to Sebastian.

~~51-100~~
Activity finally picks up again as we reach the lower half of the Top 100, which was the most active group of the bunch. Close to the 50th-place border, we find #54 Danny Gallenberger. He apparently found enough time off from MK7 to play MKWii for a bit, though only long enough to set 1 PR. #57 Daniel Crutcher cut nearly 1 point of AF with 4 PR's, and was rewarded by a 1 place cut. #58 Dylan Imhoff was also active, but not enough to avoid being displaced by Daniel. #60 Frederick Hutchington picked up a PR as well, but, like Danny and Dylan, still fell victim to the infamous AF treadmill. #63 Dilan Arse had a bit more luck there; his position didn't change, but he did cut about 1.2 AF with 2 PR's. He was only the first of a string of players who all felt like PR'ing exactly twice; #81 Qi Zhu also came up with 2 PR's, but he still fell back a bit in AF. However, he did slow his descent enough to pass 1 other player, so it wasn't a total loss for him. AF neighbors #88 Viktor Silivanov and #89 Luke Berrill both managed to cut a bit of AF with their PR pairs, though their ranks didn't change. #92 Loris Bagnasco only slightly mitigated his AF losses, but he was still better off than the players around him. #97 Sam Smith marks the end of the 2-PR streak, as he went one better than the players ahead of him. He got a solid ~1.8 AF cut and 1 place improvement for his trouble. And it's just as well that he did, because #99 Blake Germany came vaulting straight into the Top 100 all the way from 137th, and probably still has some momentum to spare. Blake apparently found some spare time left over from being the DKSC king, as he made quite a bit of progress toward balancing his timesheet. He improved a whopping 31 of his times, cutting over 50(!) AF--the biggest cut of the update by far.

~~101+~~
Meanwhile, someone who's probably not too happy with Blake right now is #101 Evan Simmons. His 5 PR's and ~3 point AF cut would have been enough to see him into the Top 100, but since Blake beat him in, he got left out in the cold. #100 Cyril Fulag is now about 2 points away, so Evan will have to keep up his progress if he wants to make it in. Lower down, #163 Stephen L kept busy with 2 PR's. He moved up 1 spot by cutting just over 1 AF, and is now just 1 place below that guy you'll be hearing from next week, Zack Weber. #166 Jacob Fitzgibbon is new to the full AF rankings; after working for some time to fill out his timesheet, he finally completed it and joined at a respectable rank in the Hero C range. And last but not least in this update is #167 Rob Jon. He updated 21 of his times for a ~15 point AF cut, jumping ahead 16 places in the rankings.


Site Records
Four Site Records have been improved since the last update, two of which have changed hands. The two that didn't belong to Blake Germany, who still rules DK Summit with an iron fist. Carter Clem picked up his first SR, dropping Steve Bernelli's total to 2, while Dylan Imhoff took Ruby Aruba's only SR to gain total domination of GBA Bowser Castle 3.

Blake Germany improved his own DK's Snowboard Cross crs time of 1'48"713 with a time of: 1'47"987
Blake Germany also improved his own DK's Snowboard Cross lap time of 0'35"022 with a time of: 0'34"543
Carter Clem beat Steve Bernelli's Maple Treeway lap time of 0'27"694 with a time of: 0'27"489
Dylan Imhoff beat Ruby Aruba's old GBA Bowser's Castle 3 lap time of 0'38"085 and got the first 38 second sub with a time of: 0'37"991


Awards
Still working on filling these out...Please be patient.


That'll do it for this update. Web should be here to bring you the news next week, so you can look forward to that. In the mean time, you can do your part to make sure you're mentioned in it; keep karting and keep sending in your times!

~MrL1193

fields.author: Webinator
fields.title: Return to Form
fields.content:
Hey everyone, Webinator here, and Im back writing news updates again.I decided to step in and fill the place of Malleo after he was removed for his cheating. Cant wait for all of the typo corrections again! Lets get to the news.

This news update covers October 19th to October 25, 2012.

The New Players
Three new players decided to join the ranks of the MKWPP faithful this week.
Benjamin Lane submitted 19 times (all courses, shocker) to start out his MKW career. Hes started to grasp some of the glitches and with practice Im sure his times will start to drop. Theoretically hes 415th now, but he can only climb from there.
Alex B mysteriously left his last name blank as he sent in 13 times to place him in the 377th position if the rest of his times were dead last. Its a good start, and with a near 1:10 LC sub already, he looks to be set for a nice climb upwards on the charts.
Thomas Gonda sent in one time, a low 1:01 on rYF. Though it took him three hours, hopefully as his MKW career goes on he wont have to take as long to lower it.


Movement
29 players were active this week.

I felt like bringing my Welcome to the AF chart segment back because its always nice when you finally get noticed on the movement section week to week, but sadly nobody joined. With our three new players not having a full timesheet and everyone else down there not wanting to leave, I guess well have to wait a few weeks. Lets get on to the actual movement.

~~The Top 10~~
Even with all of the shakeups in the last months, the Top 10 still has players that are intent on improving their ranks. #4 Thomas van Deerse knocked out two PRs on TF to knock off .2% off his AF score. Hes getting pretty close to #3 Marc Bas now, so maybe well see that pass soon. The other active player in the pinnacle of MKW TTs was #10 Leo Petiard, who had 7 PRs to his name and took off .8 AF points from his score. Among them was a set of MT glitch times that have been helping everyone still active claim some AF points off of the inactive players. Hes only a tenth off of #9 Aziz Abdullah to further secure a spot in the Top 10, so hopefully Leo keeps making these types of improvements.

~~11-25: Past Champs and Inactives~~
Three players turned on their Wiis to take down a combined 8 PRs this week. First up was #16 Alex Shoal, still managing to PR even after all of his past high-level activity. He hit a low 1:51 on DKSC, perhaps trying to keep up with recent WR activity on the track. Next was the standout of the group #23 Paul-Philipp Baehr, who had a nice four point AF cut with 6 PRs. Sadly even with that impressive showing he couldnt gain any places on the charts. The good news is hes almost cleared the entirety of the 6.5 AF graveyard that he had to traverse across. One more week like that and Fabien Jacques and Alvin Le await in the 46 AF range. Finally #25 Liam Ashcroft sent in one time to cut .2 AF, a 59.913 on rYF. One of those subs that Im sure feels really good, but Ive never experienced. :( Hes only .2 AF points away from #24 Jamie Disley, so pushing for a few more PRs should secure his spot in this group

~~26-50:The Future of MKW?~~
Yeah, no one decided to submit PRs here, from #26 Sebastian Kovats to #50 Alberto Fiorese. I guess thats good news for anyone right below them, you might want to sneak in and grab a bunch of positions while they still slumber.

~~51-100:Seizing Oppurtunities~~
Starting off this list is #56 Daniel Crutcher with 4 PRs and a 2.5 AF cut. All of the PRs were course times, and hes begun to experiment with the Spear on rSGB. Theres nobody ahead of you Daniel, so go grab some spots. Next is #64 Christian W, who apparently has no relation to the combined kart champion in the same country, had a nice distinction this week. He was the highest ranked karter to actually pass someone on the charts, moving from #65 to #64 with 8 PRs and a 2.4 AF cut and knocking down Inviso a spot. The next few players are spread out ahead of him but with PR streaks like that he should catch them soon. #79 Luke Berrill had 12 PRs that brought him from #88 to #79 and cut 10 AF points. So much for nobody passing anyone. That 8% cut was the best of the week and a massive group of 5 players with 110 AF await him only 4 AF points away. #81 Qi Zhu was a victim of this move, he PRed once but managed to only break even exactly, not gaining or losing any AF. Hopefully hell cut a little more than TF, which he appears to have been doing religiously lately, and hell be able to make AF cuts and position improvements. Last active here was #83 Jon Coppernoll, who made two improvements that couldnt really be called PRs because even though they cut 1.2 AF, he pathetically couldnt move up any places. Normally Id feel bad, but due to some activity on the combined charts recently I just cant bring myself to tears over it. Too bad Jon, work harder next week.

~~The Rest: Targeting Me for Some Reason~~
Two players were active down here, both less than five places behind me on the AF charts. #162 Stephen L, had one PR that knocked off .93 AF points from his score. Hes only about 1.2 points away from my position, so Ill probably be knocked down more next week. Good luck, I guess. Finally, #165 Jacob Fitzgibbon had one PR of his own, cutting .08 AF points and getting him marginally closer to Michael Miller and 164th. Keep playing and PRing, because nobody down here ever does. Youll move up in time, good luck!

Site Records
Only one site record was broken this week, by Paul-Philipp Baehr on newly glitched MT flap. He knocked Carter Clems time down half of a second and knocked Clem off of the Site Records table. Meanwhile, Baehr moved up to a tie for fourth with 2 SRs, adding MT to his already claimed WGM flap.

Paul-Philipp Baehr beat Carter Clems old Maple Treeway lap time of 027489 with a time of: 026945

Awards
Im going to wait to start awarding these until everything is figured out with MrL1193, so stay tuned in the coming weeks for the catching up of awards once more.

There it is, my return to news updating. Feel free to put praise/criticism on the forums, and especially all of my typos, I love those. Keep karting everyone!
~Web

fields.author: MrL1193
fields.title: Night of the Dead Living
fields.content:
Update: October 25th - November 1st


New Players
Amy Westen was the only newbie this week, joining with just 4 times. They're only good enough for approximately 421st place on their own, so hopefully Amy will follow them up with the other 60 times soon.

Movement
With Halloween providing a distraction, not many players were active this week--only 20 in all.

~~1-10~~
As we shine our flashlight into the darkness in search of the mythical Active Karters, the first (and only one in the Top 10) to step into the spotlight is #3 Thomas van Deerse. With just a few points to go to reach Champion Shaun Tanney, it seems Thomas has taken an interest in improving his glitch times for some quick AF cuts. He turned his attention to Grumble Volcano first and was rewarded with 2 PR's and nearly a full point cut from his AF, enough to pass French Champion Marc Bas. He's still separated from Nick and Shaun by a significant margin, though, so he may soon have to think up other AF-cutting tactics to reach his goal.

~~11-50~~
Hardly anyone did anything in this section, which would normally be separated into two groups. Thus, #26 Sebastian Kovats gets the attention all to himself. He only cut a very small amount of AF, but he did manage to achieve the prestigious 1:50 sub on Dry Dry Ruins, so he can still take pride in that accomplishment.

~~51-100~~
The lower half of the Top 100 accounted for more than half of this update's active players. #53 Daniel Crutcher managed to leapfrog 3 karters with 3 PR's, landing just in front of #54 Danny Gallenberger. Dan G was probably none too pleased about losing a place to Dan C's antics, but he did at least cut a bit of AF by updating an old DK Summit PR. The two Dans weren't the only ones playing in pairs, as #81 Qi Zhu and #82 Jon Coppernoll were also busy. Kezer cut a bit of AF by working on GCN Mario Circuit and continuing to improve his Toad's Factory times, while Jon played DK Summit, earning a bigger cut of ~1.9 AF and passing Yannick Wiesner.

~~101+~~
And finally, our search for things that go bump in the night wraps up with #159 Rob Jon, who, like Thomas and Sebastian, was the only player active out in his vast graveyard of a group. With updates to 8 times to report, he cut over 10 points of AF and jumped forward 7 places in the rankings.


Site Records
Surprisingly, not one Site Record was improved this week. I'm pretty sure this is just the result of infrequent submissions from certain players, though, so there will probably be a couple new SR's to report by next week.


Awards
4th POW of October: Thomas van Deerse - After persistent effort to continue his progress at the top, Thomas was finally rewarded with the #3 spot this week. He cut exactly 1 point of AF--no mean feat at this level--which was just enough to pass Marc Bas.

Sorry I didn't get around to catching up more on the awards; I'll try to fill in more of them in coming weeks, after which we'll hopefully be able to resume a regular awards schedule. See you again in two weeks!

~MrL1193

fields.author: Webinator
fields.title: New November News
fields.content:
Hey guys, Web here for another batch of news. Hope everyone had fun during Halloween and is looking forward to Thanksgiving! Were you were confused what do do on Maple Treeway and Peach Beach, and what was allowed as a non-glitch time? Well weve added them to the No Glitch Rules section of the site, amongst all of the other glitches. Thanks to Frederick Hutchington and Dexter Howe, as well as MrL1193 for all of that work. Lets get on to the weeks events.

This news update covers November 2nd to 8th, 2012.

The New Players
Nobody new joined this week, rendering this section useless. What a shame.

Movement
26 players were active this week, with no one joining the AF charts from the Land of Unfinished Timesheets.

~~The Top 10~~
The Top 10 has continued to improve week to week even after all of this time, with three players coming in this week to submit PRs. Recently crowned #3 Thomas van Deerse continued his improvement, registering a high 2:12.7 on Bowsers Castle and knocking off .0312 AF points. The gap between his position and #2 Nick Meade is slightly less than 3 AF now, so its going to be tough work to narrow the gap at this level. #7 John Brunn was next up, sending in one PR. Sadly, it wasnt enough due to other players passing him, and he still lost a bit of AF. Closing the gap week-to-week is #9 Leo Petiard, who had 3 PRs this week. He slashed almost half of an AF point, to nearly jump the entire gap to 8th place. Hes only .7 points off of Dave Tandy and then another half a point to my fellow newswriter now. A shakeup near the bottom of the Top 10 seems to be approaching.

~~11-25 ~~
The next group down also had three players competing, however this time positions were gained and lost on the charts. #14 Alex Shoal had 4 PRs, including times on Toads Factory and some nice improvements on MC glitch. He jumped up two positions this week with a 1.5 AF cut, and now sits one AF point away from 13th place. Right below him is #15 Salvatore Bellusci, one of the victims of Alexs nice week. Salvatore managed 4 PRs of his own but only cut two tenths of AF, ultimately losing to Alexs charge. Meanwhile, ex-site champ Bubbles dropped a spot in his retirement, down to a still-impressive 16th after long inactivity. The final member of this group PRing was #23 Paul-Philipp Baehr, who sent in 1 PR to cut .2 AF points. The 1:51.8 on TF cleared a little bit of the long 5 AF graveyard hes been trudging through for the past few weeks.

~~26-50~~
Again, no one submitted here, but due to the activity occurring below, this sad section of the news might have more than meaningless filler in a few weeks.

~~51-100~~
Heres where the real activity of this week began. #53 Daniel Crutcher led out the group with 2 PRs and a small AF cut. Hes closing the gap very slowly on Gary Marcoz and is only 3 AF points out of the Top 50. Luckily he wont have much to contend with once he gets to that dead zone. Watching behind him may be a problem however, since #54 Danny Gallenberger sent in a RR 3lap to cut .15 AF points and bring himself only three tenths away from catching Daniel. The two now can fight against each other and the inactive zombies as they race up the charts. #64 Christian W had a .15 AF cut with 3 PRs, chipping away slightly at the players in front of him. Next up was all-around MK standout #74 Stacy Needham, who had a 1:54 on DKSC that cut off a tenth of AF. #79 Luke Berrill had one impressive PR on rWS that accounted for a 1.5 AF cut. He couldnt pass any players but still managed to close the gap between himself and Chaos. Closing out the group was #80 Jon Coppernoll, who redeemed himself from an atrocious showing two weeks ago and sent in two PRs to cut 1.7 AF points and pass two players, the best jump of the week. Luke is about three points away through so hell need two more weeks like that to attempt another pass.

~~Everyone Else~~
Two players sent in times here, starting with #122 Dexter Howe. Sending in one PR, he cut .4 AF and jumped past Lars Riecken to secure another spot on the rankings. Finally, #163 Stephen L submitted one time, cutting .6 AF points and drawing ever closer to knocking me down another spot on the rankings.

Site Records
Two site records were conquered this week, both on the always-active glitchy Maple Treeway. Steve Bernelli improved his own course time while snatching the flap. Due to this, there wasnt much movement on the Site Record Movement Table. Steve Bernelli moved up to a tie for 3rd with Toad Norton with his 3 SRs, while Paul-Philipp fell down to a tie for 17th, with all of the other one SR players. It seems track specialists still reign supreme even years after MKWs release.

Steve Bernelli beat his own Maple Treeway crs time of 2'02"706 with a time of: 2'02"417
Steve Bernelli beat Paul-Philipp Baehrs old Maple Treeway lap time of 0'26"945 with a time of: 0'26"700

Awards
These will happen soon, just making sure everything is caught up first. In the meantime just keep karting so youll be awarded one once everything is ready once more.

Well, thats it for this week. Thanks for reading and keep karting everyone!
~Web

fields.author: MrL1193
fields.title: Just when you thought it couldn't get any stranger...
fields.content:
Update: November 8th - November 15th

Hey guys, John here, ready to deliver your weekly news. The big story this week is that a new strategy was discovered for Coconut Mall's already-glitchy fast lap; it involves jumping up on the edge of the grass in the parking lot to trip the finish line checkpoint in a better location and then circling around to complete the lap in under 5 seconds. Naturally, a flurry of activity ensued, with players of various ranks all eager to try it out. Let's take a closer look at how everyone fared, shall we?

New Players
The only rookie to join this week was Steven Reinhold. He got off to a solid start, earning a theoretical rank of 251st with 40 PR's, and seems motivated to improve from there. Hopefully he'll also fill in the rest of his lap times as he progresses.

Movement
A fairly average 28 players sent in new times this week, though none of them were players completing their timesheets to join the rankings.

~~The Top 10~~
For the most part, the foremost MKW players seem to remain constant in their activity or inactivity. Current champ Shaun Tanney and former longtime champ Nick Meade, for instance, usually slumber on, oblivious of the players below them. This, of course, provides opportunities for constantly active players like #3 Thomas van Deerse to creep up through the rankings. Thomas has been busy improving his Moo Moo Meadows course time lately, which earned him a small AF cut this week. #7 John Brunn has been focusing on a single course as well--N64 Bowser's Castle, in his case--but since he didn't improve his rank as much as Thomas did, he still suffered a loss in AF. As such, he's in #8 Leo Petiard's crosshairs now. Leo improved both his course and lap times on Coconut Mall, making a significant cut in AF. He passed Dave Tandy, and seems ready to press on to catch John.

~~11-25~~
Last week, #14 Alex Shoal and #15 Salvatore Bellusci were both active, each submitting 4 PR's. This week, they repeated their previous week's performance, making solid AF cuts. This time, it was Salvatore who got the bigger cut, though it wasn't enough to trade places with Alex. Unlike last week, #23 Paul-Philipp Baehr didn't put in an appearance, but #24 Liam Ashcroft did. He submitted improvements to several of his flaps, earning a nice ~2.4 AF cut, and is now a mere ~.6 AF away from subbing 50 points. Unfortunately, his rank didn't change because he's currently caught in an AF dead zone, but the going should get easier if he can catch up with Paul.

~~26-50~~
As is often the case lately, this section was quite quiet. #34 Marvin Donjes popped in out of MK7 land to try out the new Coconut Mall flap strategy, keeping his AF backsliding to a minimum by staying ahead of others who attempted it. And just now joining the group is #50 Daniel Crutcher, who somehow found time to both defend his Coconut Mall flap record and improve other times for a grand total of 7 PR's. He cut ~3.3 AF, passed 3 players, and pulled his AF under the 80 point mark--not a bad for just one week's work.

~~51-100~~
Meanwhile, fellow Dan #54 Danny Gallenberger was busy as well this week. In addition to the obligatory Coconut Mall flap improvement, he also submitted several improvements to both his Rainbow Road times during the week, cutting ~.9 AF. #64 Christian W bucked the trend of the week by getting a 2:33.4 on N64 Bowser's Castle instead. It ended up cutting almost half a point from his AF total, so it must have been a pretty solid improvement over his previous time. And our last active player in the Top 100, #74 Luke Berrill didn't bother with Coconut Mall either, instead submitting 3 PR's on various other courses. He cut ~2.6 AF and leaped forward 5 spots in the rankings just so this section could be all about people whose ranks end in the number 4.

~~101+~~
#118 Dexter Howe leads the post-100 activity section, as he often does. As expected, he gave the Coconut Mall flap strategy a try, but he also managed to finish his first Maple Treeway glitched run, though he was extremely dissatisfied with it. His AF cut was nothing to sneeze at, however, at nearly 4 points, and he also rose 4 places--an average of 2 places with each PR. I'm sure many players wish they could say the same about their week's PR's. #154 Rob Jon didn't do too badly himself, though, improving by 5 places and almost 8 AF with just 6 PR's. #166 Jacob Fitzgibbon wasn't quite so lucky, as he didn't move up, but he did cut a bit of AF with his 2 PR's, which is much better than free falling like the players around him. And wrapping up this week's activity is #346 Stephen de Winter, who also submitted 2 PR's. He cut ~5.2 AF, shooting past 7 of the closely packed karters in the road ahead of him.


Site Records
As expected, the scene of most of this week's Site Record activity was Coconut Mall's parking lot of ethereal cars and curbs. Many players were scrambling to seize the now-vulnerable SR, but when the dust settled, it was instead the Mario Circuit course record that had a new owner. Michael Penninck claimed his first SR there, pulling Tony Ros down to join him among the 29 players tied for 16th with 1 SR each.

Michael Penninck beat Tony Ros's old Mario Circuit crs time of 1'04"984 with a time of: 1'04"461
Daniel Crutcher fought off all challengers to retain his Coconut Mall lap record. From his old time of 0'05"607, he made numerous improvements, ending the week with a time of: 0'04"351 It is now the lowest lap time on the site, just barely beating out Grumble Volcano's.
Steve Bernelli improved his own Maple Treeway lap time of 0'26"700 with a time of: 0'26"406


Awards
1st POW of November: Thomas van Deerse - Not content to stop at earning the bronze medal, Thomas continued to press on. He earned 5 PR's this week, cutting more than a full point of AF--a rarity at such a high level.
2nd POW of November: Liam Ashcroft - Liam was the only player to exceed a 4% cut in AF this week. 5 solid PR's knocked ~2.36 points off his AF.

I still haven't finished catching up on the old awards that certain cheaters rendered invalid, but that doesn't mean we have to let newer awards pile up as well. We'll do our best to make sure you keep getting the awards you deserve every week. Remember, these aren't just for a select few players to monopolize--if you keep making strides every week, you're bound to get noticed sooner or later. So keep on karting!

~MrL1193

fields.author: Webinator
fields.title: Still Recovering from the Food Coma...
fields.content:
Whats up everyone, its time for another round of MKW news. If you havent checked out the MKW forums recently, Alex Shoal has been running a GOAT of GOATs competition to see who is the communitys pick for the greatest player ever, and its getting down to the final rounds. You should go check it out if you havent already. Lets get on to the weeks news.

This news update covers November 16nd to 22nd, 2012.

The New Players
No newbies this week.

Movement
22 players karted this week, and no one finished up their timesheet from the Land of Unfinished Timesheets.

~~The Top 10~~
The Top 10 seems to keep the same players active week to week.
